newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile Enami workers resist modernizing - Teplizky.
newsitem.headline: Chile Enami workers resist modernizing - Teplizky.

text.p: Chile's mining minister chided the union at the state-owned Ventanas copper refinery for resisting ''modernization'' a few weeks before its wage contract expires.
''Anything can happen'' in contract talks at the plant, owned by Empresa Nacional de Mineria, or Enami, said Mining Minister Benjamin Teplizky.

''At this time we are negotiating with Ventanas, whose union has a tradition of being strong and reluctant to modernize in some aspects, in my opinion. Therefore anything can happen,'' Teplizky told a news conference.
Teplizky's words were the first hint of problems in wage talks at Ventanas. Union officials were not available for comment.
The labor contract at Ventanas near Vina del Mar expires January 31. The plant was paralyzed by a 10-day strike in early 1995 when its wage contract last come up for renewal.
Enami Vice President Claudio Agostini, who was also at the news conference, said there were no problems in wage talks at Ventanas but declined to give details.
Teplizky said Enami had closed five-year wage contracts with 10 other unions, including those at its Paipote smelter near the northern city of Copiapo.
